fields.label: Term
fields.description: Canonical name of the concept. Use title case for multiword terms (e.g., 'Subordinate clause'). Must be unique across the dataset.

fields.label: Definition
fields.description: Primary explanation of the concept in plain English. Should stand alone without relying on examples. Avoid circularity unless unavoidable; prefer definitional clarity over completeness.

fields.label: Compressed Definition
fields.description: Short memory-oriented paraphrase (typically 2–6 words). Should preserve the core meaning and be usable as a flashcard back.

fields.label: Tags
fields.description: Flexible categorization (subfield, theme, pedagogy). Use a small set of stable tokens (e.g., 'Syntax', 'Semantics', 'methodology'). Not a prose description.

fields.label: Examples
fields.description: Optional clarifying examples. Each example MUST be one of: (1) a diagnostic question, (2) a contrast pair (X vs Y), or (3) a boundary case. If none add value beyond the definition, omit (use an empty array). Do not include merely 'the term used in a sentence' examples.

fields.label: Notes
fields.description: Optional details, caveats, scope limits, or theoretical remarks. Use to record ambiguity, competing analyses, or implementation guidance.

fields.label: Links
fields.description: Concept links (terms) related to this entry. Prefer links that meaningfully support understanding (contrast classes, components, close neighbors). A link is 'external' if it does not resolve to any defined term in the dataset.

description: Structured linguistic knowledge as a cross-collection concept graph. Each entry defines a term and links to related terms; a link is 'external' if it does not resolve to any defined term in the dataset.

example_policy.rule: Examples must clarify the concept, not merely use the term in a sentence.
